body:
Does Alacritty freeze completely, or does it just stop redrawing?

If it is frozen completely, can you share the gdb backtrace?
it doesn't seem to respond to anything except Ctrl+C (if started from a shell), can test more things tomorrow
I've also had this issue using alacritty within i3 on X11. Downgrading does solve the problem. I'll install alacritty with debug symbols and see what's happening when I get a chance.

@JOT85 is downgrading alacritty fixes it? If so could you bisect? Could you test before and after 0e418bc2f761617455cc58aaabc375055dfe4284 commit? I have a feeling that it's the issue @chrisduerr had the other day with locking on X11.


Otherwise you could try running this branch https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/pull/6958 it should have the bug fixed.

I have one laptop (amd cpu and gpu) and one desktop (amd cpu and nvidia), both with endeavouros.
Both use dwm
Just recently upgrade both of them.
The laptop 100% chance freeze after a resize or swap between two pane.
Using master branch, it also freeze
Downgrade to 11.0-2 solved the issue on the laptop. (Downgrade to 12.0-1 also have this freezing issue)

But the desktop is fine with 12.1-1
@amalgame21 have you tried the branch I've linked (#6958)?

`git clone https://github.com/kchibisov/alacritty -b winit-update`.

If you have a clone of my repo already, you could `git fetch` and then `git checkout winit-update`, but what I said will give you desirable result.

@kchibisov I tested your branch and the freezing problem seems fixed for my laptop. 
But your branch have a huge red Error prompt which make it unusable.

Yeah, the error thing is expected it simply tells that your bindings are not compatible with the branch, because keyboard input changed. it'll work without any messages once you resolve the issue (comment out your bindings or update the way they look on the posted branch).

you could simply press `cross` on that bar though.

I pointed that branch, because it accumulates all the changes from the upstream windowing crates meaningful to alacritty to simplify transition.

issue.title: Update to the new winit keyboard API
issue.body:
The main highlight of this update is that alacritty will now use new
keyboard API from the winit, which resolves a lot of issues around
key bindings, such as ability to bind dead keys. It also fixes long
standing issues with the virtual key code bindings and make bindings in
general more predictable. It also makes our default Vi key bindings
fully working.

Given that alacritty was using `VirtualKey` directly in the bindings
from the winit, and winit simply removed the enum, we've added internal
conversions to minimize the fallout, but new way to specify the bindings
should be more intuitive.

Other part of this update fixes some forward compatibility bugs with the
Wayland backend, given that wayland-rs 0.30 is fully forward compatible.
The update also fixes weird Maximized startup issues on GNOME Wayland,
however they were present on any sane compositor.

Fixes #6842.
Fixes #6455.
Fixes #6184.
Fixes #5684.
Fixes #3574.
Fixes #3460.
Fixes #1336.
Fixes #892.
Fixes #458.
Fixes #55.

body:
Carrying over the discussion from https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/6971 to this issue, since it seems like a duplicate.

Posted relevant additional info in the [issue description](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/6971#issue-1736950032) and in this [comment](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/6971#issuecomment-1577195187). 

I'll test @kchibisov's solution after work and update this comment :)

I have the same issue on 0.12.1 using Arch Linux and DWM. The window freezes/crashes quite reliably on heavy resizing (like opening many windows on a tiling WM).

Moreover, I personally run a single instance of Alacritty and open every additional window using `alacritty msg create-window`. A freeze causes *all* Alacritty windows to freeze -- quite annoying.

Building from newest commit 2ad28b5 seems to fix the issue. @kchibisov's branch works too. Please let me know if you need more information or some `bisect`ing -- my reproducible test is `zathura *.pdf` in a directory with a bunch of PDFs btw (on a tiling WM).
@marvinborner I know what broke it, it's basically ensuring that it's the same root cause. no bisect is required.
